Detailed Description

Pathname identifying a file relative to a storage device.

Class Pathname simplifies the construction of valid pathnames which locate files and directories within some dedicated storage device. Class Pathname supports absolute pathnames only, relative pathnames are not supported. Moreover, symbols like .. for the parent directory or . for the current directory are not supported. Although there might be different storage devices available on the mobile station, class Pathname ignores this fact and only uniquely identifies a file or directory with respect to a distinct storage device. I.e. a pathname does not store the storage device Id string! To uniquely identify a file or directory in the system use class Path which holds the storage device Id string and the pathname.

A pathname consists of segments separated by slashes /. A valid pathname is either the root pathname / or any sequence of slash-segment pairs. A segment is any string not containing any slashes. A segment is allowed to have as many dots . as wanted, thereby supporting extensions. The size of a pathname is not limited. See the following EBNF grammar: 

    pathname      = root_pathname | "/" segment { "/" segment }.
    root_pathname = "/".
    segment       = segment_part { "." segment_part }.
    segment_part  = character { character }.

Samples for valid pathnames are:

  • /
  • /mydir
  • /mydir.ext
  • /myfilename
  • /myfilename.ext
  • /mydir/mysubdir
  • /ffs/mydir/mysubdir/myfilename.ext
  • /mydir.ext/myfilename
  • /ffs/mydir.ext/myfilename.ext.ext

Not valid pathnames are:

  • //
  • /mydir/
  • mydir
  • mydir.ext/
  • myfilename
  • myfilename.ext

The string arguments to methods of class Pathname may specify leading or trailing slashes. However, the provided methods try to combine the string arguments with the current pathname in a way that a valid pathname results, e.g., missing separators will be added and adjacent separators will be removed. However, these methods only care for correct concatenation of the argument strings to the current pathname, the argument strings themselves are not checked for validity. Hence, after having constructed a pathname which was constructed with possibly invalid string arguments, e.g. if you construct the pathname using not validated user input, use method IsValid() for checking if the resulting pathname really is ok.

Many functions return a BOOLEAN value stating if the pathname was modified or not. This information might be useful when interactively constructing pathnames to give feedback to the user. If this information is not needed it can simply be ignored. A final check with IsValid() will be enough, too.

The following sample function shows how to use the pathname API:

    static BOOLEAN ConstructPathname()
    {
        Pathname pathname("/dir");

        pathname.Add("subdir");
        pathname.Add("/file");
        pathname.AddFileExtension("txt");
        pathname.AddFileExtension(".doc");
        // The resulting pathname is "/dir/subdir/file.txt.doc".

        WString last_segment = pathname.GetLeaf();
        // The leaf is "file.txt.doc".

        WString file_extension = pathname.GetFileExtension();
        // The file extension is "doc".

        pathname.RemoveFileExtension();
        // The resulting pathname is "/dir/subdir/file.txt".

        pathname.RemoveLeaf();
        // The pathname name is now "/dir/subdir".

        if (!pathname.IsValid()) {
            // The constructed pathname is not valid syntactically. In this example
            // actually the pathname must be valid! However, if you ask a filename
            // from the user then you can validate with this function if it is
            // syntactically correct. Syntactical correctness doesn't tell anything
            // about existence of the file.
            return FALSE;
        }

        return TRUE;
}

Member Enumeration Documentation

anonymous enum
 

Enumerator:
MAX_PATHNAME_LENGTH  The size of a pathname is not limited. However, the size of a pathname that shall be persisted via class PathProfile is limited due to the current persisting mechanism applied. A pathname to be persisted is limited to MAX_PATHNAME_LENGTH characters including the terminating 0 character, i.e. there may be at most MAX_PATHNAME_LENGTH - 1 significant characters in a pathname to be persisted.

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

Pathname::Pathname (   ) 
 

Constructs a pathname initialized to the root pathname /.

Pathname::Pathname (  const WString &  str  ) 
 

Constructs a pathname for str. If str is empty then the pathname for the root pathname / is constructed. A missing leading separator will be added and redundant trailing separators will be removed.

Parameters:
str The string describing a file or directory.

Pathname::Pathname (  const Pathname &  pathname  ) 
 

Copy constructor.

Pathname::~Pathname (   ) 
 

Destroys this pathname object.

Member Function Documentation

BOOLEAN Pathname::Add (  const Pathname &  pathname  ) 
 

Adds the specified pathname.

See also:
Add(const WString &str)

BOOLEAN Pathname::Add (  const WString &  str  ) 
 

Adds the specified str. If str is empty or the root pathname / then nothing is done. A missing leading separator will be added and redundant trailing separators will be removed. Adjacent separators will be unified. Please see the following example:

            Pathname pathname("dir/");
            // Results in "/dir".

            pathname.Add("/subdir1/subdir2/");
            // Results in "/dir/subdir1/subdir2".

            pathname.Add("filename.ext/");
            // Results in "/dir/subdir1/subdir2/filename.ext".

Parameters:
str The string to add.
Returns:
Tells if str was added.

BOOLEAN Pathname::AddFileExtension (  MimeType  type  ) 
 

Adds a file extension representing MIME type type. There is no check if a file extension is already present, therefor any number of file extensions can be added by subsequent calls. The extension is added with a dot.

Parameters:
type The MIME type defining the extension to append.
Returns:
Tells if the file extension was added.

BOOLEAN Pathname::AddFileExtension (  const WString &  file_extension  ) 
 

Adds a file extension. There is no check if a file extension is already present, therefor any number of file extensions can be added by subsequent calls. The provided file_extension may start with a dot, if it is missing, it is added. A file extension must not start with a slash, in this case it can't be added. The try to add a file extension immediately after a segment separator, i.e. the root pathname /, will fail.

Parameters:
file_extension The file extension to add, with or without the dot ..
Returns:
Tells if file_extension was added.

Pathname::Iterator Pathname::Begin (   )  const
 

Returns the begin iterator which either points to the first segment of the pathname or is equal to the end iterator if the pathname contains no segments.

Pathname::Iterator Pathname::End (   )  const
 

Returns the end iterator which points to the end of the pathname. It is the first iterator which doesn't point to a valid segment any more. The end iterator has one past the end semantics.

WString Pathname::GetExtensionSeparator (   )  [static]
 

Returns the extension separator character as a string.

WString Pathname::GetFileExtension (   )  const
 

Returns the last file extension. The extension is returned without the dot. Please see the following example:

            Pathname pathname("file");
            // The resulting pathname is "/file".

            pathname.AddFileExtension("txt");
            // The resulting pathname is "/file.txt".

            pathname.AddFileExtension(".doc");
            // The resulting pathname is "/file.txt.doc"

            WString file_extension = pathname.GetFileExtension();
            // The file extension retrieved is "doc".

Returns:
The last file extension without the dot or an empty string object if a file extension is not present.

WString Pathname::GetHead (   )  const
 

Returns a string object containing the first pathname segment. This is used to get the top level directory name.

WString Pathname::GetLeaf (   )  const
 

Returns a string object containing the last pathname segment. This is used to get the file or directory name stripped of any leading directories.

MimeType Pathname::GetMimeType (   )  const
 

Returns the MIME type corresponding to the file extension. If no file extension is present or there is no MIME type defined for the current file extension then c_mime_unknown is returned.

Returns:
The MIME type of the pathname.

WString Pathname::GetSegmentAt (  UINT  segment_idx  )  const
 

Returns the pathname segment at the given index segment_idx. If segment_idx is out of range the empty string is returned.

Parameters:
segment_idx The zero-based index of the segment.
Returns:
A string containing the pathname segment at index segment_idx or the empty string if the index is out of range.

UINT Pathname::GetSegmentCount (   )  const
 

Returns the number of segments. */.

WString Pathname::GetSeparator (   )  [static]
 

Returns the separator character as a string.

WString Pathname::GetStrippedFileName (   )  const
 

Returns the file or directory name stripped of any leading directories and the last extension.

BOOLEAN Pathname::HasExtension (   )  const
 

Tells if the pathname has an extension.

BOOLEAN Pathname::HasLeaf (   )  const
 

Tells if the pathname has a leaf.

void Pathname::Init (  const WString &  str  ) 
 

Initializes the pathname to str.

BOOLEAN Pathname::IsRoot (   )  const
 

Returns TRUE if the pathname is equal to root pathname. The return value is FALSE in all other cases.

BOOLEAN Pathname::IsValid (   )  const
 

Tells if this pathname complies with the pathname syntax. Syntactical correctness doesn't tell anything about existence of the file. Actually, if you programmatically build a filename then you can assure without calling this function that the resulting pathname conforms to the pathname syntax, provided you used a correct initialization string on construction. However, if you ask a filename from the user then you can validate with this function if it is syntactically correct.

BOOLEAN Pathname::operator!= (  const Pathname &  rhs  )  const [inline]
 

Compares this pathname to pathname rhs for inequality. The comparison is a mere string compare.

Returns:
Compare result.

BOOLEAN Pathname::operator== (  const Pathname &  rhs  )  const
 

Compares this pathname to pathname rhs. The comparison is a mere string compare.

Returns:
Compare result.

BOOLEAN Pathname::RemoveFileExtension (   ) 
 

Removes the last file extension inclusive the dot ..

Returns:
Tells if the file extension was removed.

BOOLEAN Pathname::RemoveHead (   ) 
 

Removes the first segment of the pathname. If the pathname is the root pathname nothing is done.

Returns:
Tells if the head was removed.

BOOLEAN Pathname::RemoveLeaf (   ) 
 

Removes the last segment of the pathname. If the pathname is the root pathname then nothing is done.

Returns:
Tells if the leaf was removed.

void Pathname::RemoveTrailingSeparators (   )  [protected]
 

Removes any trailing separators. If there is no trailing separator the pathname is unchanged.

void Pathname::Reset (   ) 
 

Resets the pathname to the root pathname.

Pathname::ReverseIterator Pathname::ReverseBegin (   )  const
 

Returns the reverse begin iterator which either points to the last segment of the pathname or is equal to the reverse end iterator if the pathname contains no segments.

Pathname::ReverseIterator Pathname::ReverseEnd (   )  const
 

Returns the reverse end iterator which points to the start of the pathname. It is the first reverse iterator which doesn't point to a valid segment any more. The end reverse iterator has one before the first semantics.

BOOLEAN Pathname::SetFileExtension (  MimeType  type  ) 
 

Sets the last file extension representing MIME type type. If a file extension is present it is replaced by the specified one. If no file extension is present then the specified one will be added.

Parameters:
type The MIME type defining the extension to set.
Returns:
Tells if the file extension was set.

BOOLEAN Pathname::SetFileExtension (  const WString &  file_extension  ) 
 

Sets the last file extension to file_extension. If a file extension is present it is replaced by the specified one. If no file extension is present then the specified one will be added.

Parameters:
file_extension The file extension to set, with or without the dot ..
Returns:
Tells if the file extension was set.

const WString & Pathname::ToWString (   )  const
 

Returns a WString object containing the pathname.
